Emergency Response Program: 

This Risk Management Plan includes the required information referenced in 40 CFR §68.180 to be reported for a Program 2 process.

These employees may also perform activities under the specialist employee definition as defined by 1910.120. These personnel receive annual training on activation of the facility emergency action

To assure that the local municipal response agencies are familiar with Kiros emergency response procedures and copies of the all-emergency action plans have been shared with and reviewed by local responders. In the event of a significant release of propane that involve off site populations, these populations will be notified through the LEPC.

Planned changes to improve safety: 

Railcar storage at this facility was initiated in August of 2017.  Compliance with Kiros environmental, health and safety standards and expectations forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  

Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the facility include:
 
--Compliance audits will be conducted to evaluate compliance with the CAP provisions and to evaluate improvement opportunities.
--Coordination with the Fort Edward Fire Department will continue to ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies.
--Additional improvements will be implemented as a result of FSA and hazard review recommendations. 

Registration: 

This registration includes the required information referenced in 40 CFR §68.160(b)(1) through (20) to be reported for a Program 2 process. 

Offsite Consequence Analysis: 

As a Program 2 process with a regulated flammable substance, an offsite consequence analysis (OCA) has been performed for at least one worst-case release scenario and at least one alternative release scenario.  The required data from the OCA is contained within this Risk Management Plan

spections conducted by SMS Rail Service personnel, the site is also occupied by SMS employees on a routine basis.  An adjacent rail yard facility operated by Canada Pacific Railroad is also frequently occupied.  These entities can contact SMS Rail Service immediately if there are indications of a release, safety hazard or other condition which could reasonably be assumed to result in a hazardous situation.
--Periodic railcar inspections are conducted per an established schedule and in compliance with United States Department of Transportation (DOT) regulations.
--While the railcars are in the yard, SMS Rail Service conducts periodic safety inspections of the railcars and surrounding property.
--SMS Rail Services conducts, or arranges for, railcar maintenance as needed while the railcars are on site based on inspection results or established maintenance intervals.
--Safety information has been developed for the covered process chemical, process and equipment.
--A hazard review consisting of a Fire Safety Analysis (FSA) and hazard analysis checklist.

Five-year accident history: 

There have been no accidental releases from the covered process that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage within the last five years.  This statement does not incorporate other processing operations at the location not under the control of Kiros/SMS Rail Services or any other previous site operators. 

Emergency Response Program: 

Kiros and the contract operator have documented emergency response plans and procedures in place at the Global Fort Edward Rail Facilty to respond to and safety mitigate any release or accident involving propane. Included in the emergency response plan are measures to be taken internally by Kiros contract operators to control the release, if possible, and to make initial notification to local responders and to Kiros headqua

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policy: 

Kiros and its contractor operator, SMS Rail Service, operates the Global Fort Edward Rail Yard in a manner that prevents significant incidents or substantial threats of incidents through adherence to legal requirements, management systems, procedures and personnel training.  Kirosl understands the shared value of safety and environmental protection for our employees, the public and the communities we serve as a vital component of our energy infrastructure. 

Stationary source and regulated substance: 

The Global Fort Edward Rail Yard is leased by Kiros Energy Marketing ULC, headquartered in Calgary, Alberta. Operations at the site are performed by SMS Rail Service, Inc. (SMS).  At the rail yard, railcars of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) are stored on railroad tracks, while awaiting future transportation to another storage location or destination facility for off-load.  

LPG consisting of primarily propane and butane are the Chemical Accident Prevention (CAP) regulated chemicals stored at the rail yard which exceeds a threshold quantity.   

General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps: 

The Global Fort Edward Rail Yard is normally unmanned by Kiros and SMS Rail Service personnel.  The site is visited periodically by SMS Rail Service employees for inspection purposes and to perform operating and maintenance tasks.  As such, the facility is considered a normally unoccupied remote facility and is not subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.

The Global Fort Edward Rail Yard is regulated as a Program Level 2, CAP facility.  General accidental release prevention programs and LPG-specific release prevention steps incorporated for the covered process include the following: 

--The rail yard is a secured facility, with locked gates to limit entry to authorized personnel only.  In addition to periodic in
